title: Similarity
description: Understand similarity and scale factors, prove triangles similar using AA, SSS~, and SAS~ theorems, solve real-world proportion problems, and apply the geometric mean in right triangles with altitude-on-hypotenuse.
goals: Understand similarity and find scale factors between similar figures
Prove triangles similar using AA, SSS~, and SAS~ theorems
Apply similarity to solve real-world proportion problems
Use the geometric mean in right triangles
instructionalStrategy: Distinguish similarity from congruence: same shape but possibly different size (congruence is a special case of similarity with scale factor 1).
AA Similarity is the most commonly used—if two angles match, the triangles MUST be similar (the third angle is forced by the angle sum theorem).
Use proportions systematically: corresponding sides are in the same ratio. Write ratios consistently (small/large or large/small, but stay consistent).
Geometric mean connects to altitude-on-hypotenuse: the altitude creates two triangles similar to each other AND to the original.

scaffold.title: Similarity and Triangle Similarity Theorems
scaffold.text:
Two figures are **similar** (symbol: ~) if:
1. All corresponding angles are congruent
2. All corresponding sides are proportional

The **scale factor** is the ratio of corresponding sides. If △ABC ~ △DEF with sides 3, 4, 5 and 6, 8, 10, the scale factor is 1:2 (or 2:1 depending on direction).

**Three ways to prove triangles similar:**
• **AA (Angle-Angle)** — two pairs of congruent angles (the third is automatic)
• **SSS~ (Side-Side-Side)** — all three pairs of sides proportional
• **SAS~ (Side-Angle-Side)** — two pairs of sides proportional AND the included angle congruent
scaffold.initialPrompt: Congruent figures are similar with a scale factor of 1. What does a scale factor of 3 mean in practical terms—like a 3:1 model of a building?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Identifying Similar Triangles

examples.problem: △ABC has angles 50°, 60°, 70°. △DEF has angles 60°, 70°, 50°. Are they similar? By which theorem?
examples.solution:
Compare angles: ∠A=50°=∠F, ∠B=60°=∠D, ∠C=70°=∠E.
Two (all three) pairs congruent → **AA Similarity**.
△ABC ~ △FDE (matching equal angles in correspondence).

With AA, we only NEED two pairs. The third is guaranteed by the angle sum theorem.

examples.problem: Triangle 1 has sides 6, 9, 12. Triangle 2 has sides 10, 15, 20. Are they similar?
examples.solution:
Check all three ratios: 6/10 = 3/5, 9/15 = 3/5, 12/20 = 3/5.
All ratios equal → **SSS~ Similarity** with scale factor **3:5**.

Always match shortest-to-shortest, middle-to-middle, longest-to-longest.

examples.problem: In △PQR and △STU: PQ = 6, ST = 8, QR = 9, TU = 12, and ∠Q = ∠T = 48°. Are they similar?
examples.solution:
Two pairs of sides: PQ/ST = 6/8 = 3/4, QR/TU = 9/12 = 3/4. ✓ Proportional.
Included angle: ∠Q = ∠T = 48° ✓

By **SAS~ Similarity**, △PQR ~ △STU with scale factor **3:4**.

scaffold.initialPrompt: Why is AA sufficient? Why don't we need to check sides too? Think about what happens when you fix two angles of a triangle.

This matches SAS~: two proportional sides and included congruent angle.

problems.answer: Yes, by AA (vertical angles congruent + both have 55°)
hints: Vertical angles at C are congruent. That's one pair.

scaffold.title: Proportions and Scale Factor Applications
scaffold.text:
When triangles are similar, corresponding sides are **proportional**. Set up a proportion to find missing sides:

If △ABC ~ △DEF with scale factor k, then:
AB/DE = BC/EF = AC/DF = k

**Cross-multiplication** solves proportions: if a/b = c/d, then ad = bc.

**Real-world applications:**
• Shadow problems (sun creates similar triangles)
• Map scales (small:large ratio)
• Indirect measurement (mirror method, similar triangle method)

Key rule: always match corresponding sides consistently. If the first ratio is small/large, keep ALL ratios small/large.
scaffold.initialPrompt: A map has a scale of 1 inch = 3 miles. If two cities are 4.5 inches apart on the map, how far apart are they in real life?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Proportion and Scale Factor Problems

examples.problem: △PQR ~ △STU with scale factor 3:5. If PQ = 9 and QR = 12, find ST and TU.
examples.solution:
Scale factor from △PQR to △STU is 3:5, so multiply by 5/3.

ST (corresponds to PQ): 9/ST = 3/5 → ST = 9 × 5/3 = **15**
TU (corresponds to QR): 12/TU = 3/5 → TU = 12 × 5/3 = **20**

Verify: 9/15 = 3/5 ✓, 12/20 = 3/5 ✓

examples.problem: A 6-foot person casts a 4-foot shadow. A tree casts a 20-foot shadow at the same time. How tall is the tree?
examples.solution:
The sun creates similar triangles (same angle of elevation).

person height / person shadow = tree height / tree shadow
6/4 = x/20

Cross multiply: 4x = 120 → x = **30 feet**

Verify: 6/4 = 1.5, 30/20 = 1.5 ✓

examples.problem: On a map, 2 cm represents 15 km. Two cities are 7 cm apart on the map. Find the actual distance.
examples.solution:
Set up proportion: 2 cm / 15 km = 7 cm / x km

Cross multiply: 2x = 105 → x = **52.5 km**

Verify: 2/15 = 7/52.5 = 0.1333... ✓

scaffold.title: Geometric Mean and Right Triangle Altitude Theorem
scaffold.text:
**Geometric Mean and Right Triangle Altitude Theorem:**

When an altitude is drawn from the right angle to the hypotenuse of a right triangle, it creates two smaller triangles that are each similar to the original and to each other.

This gives us three important relationships:

1. **Altitude Rule:** altitude² = (segment 1)(segment 2)
   The altitude is the geometric mean of the two segments of the hypotenuse.

2. **Leg Rule:** leg² = (adjacent segment)(hypotenuse)
   Each leg is the geometric mean of the adjacent hypotenuse segment and the whole hypotenuse.

The **geometric mean** of two numbers a and b is √(ab).
scaffold.initialPrompt: The geometric mean of 4 and 9 is √(4×9) = √36 = 6. Notice that 6 is between 4 and 9. Can you find the geometric mean of 3 and 12?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Geometric Mean Applications

examples.problem: Find the geometric mean of 6 and 24.
examples.solution:
Geometric mean = √(a × b) = √(6 × 24) = √144 = **12**

Notice: 12 is between 6 and 24. The geometric mean is always between the two numbers.

examples.problem: In a right triangle, an altitude from the right angle to the hypotenuse divides it into segments of 4 and 9. Find the altitude.
examples.solution:
By the Altitude Rule: altitude² = (segment 1)(segment 2)
altitude² = 4 × 9 = 36
altitude = √36 = **6**

The altitude is the geometric mean of the two hypotenuse segments.

examples.problem: Using the same right triangle (hypotenuse segments 4 and 9, hypotenuse = 13), find both legs.
examples.solution:
By the Leg Rule: leg² = (adjacent segment)(full hypotenuse)

Shorter leg (adjacent to 4): leg² = 4 × 13 = 52 → leg = √52 = **2√13 ≈ 7.21**
Longer leg (adjacent to 9): leg² = 9 × 13 = 117 → leg = √117 = **3√13 ≈ 10.82**

Verify with Pythagorean Theorem: (2√13)² + (3√13)² = 52 + 117 = 169 = 13² ✓

scaffold.initialPrompt: The geometric mean is found with the formula √(a × b). How does this connect to the altitude creating similar triangles?
